results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on developing and validating a novel item response model (Soft Grades) for representing grades as probability distributions. (e.g., 'In this paper, we introduce a novel item response model and inference method...')
Sections 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the model development, parameter estimation, ability inference, and grade distribution generation.
The document mentions the use of the publicly available Open University Learning Analytics Dataset (OULAD) [28].
While the document mentions using data from two R1 university courses (C1 and C2), it states this data is 'non-public' and does not provide access.
While the datasets are described, a detailed data dictionary or codebook explaining variables, formats, and preprocessing steps is not provided within the document.

Data collection methods are described, stating that data was collected from course assessments (homework, exams) and student scores were used. (e.g., '...based off their inferred ability, after observing all of their course assessment grades.')
The document states that a web application and Python scripts implementing the model are available at https://juliettewoodrow.github.io/softgrades/.
Code is shared, so this criterion is not applicable.
The document states that the linked Python scripts include code for data preparation (e.g., pre-processing).
Statistical tests, models (Item Response Theory, Logit-Normal distributions), and assumptions (normality of student abilities) are clearly described.
Effect sizes (likelihoods), confidence intervals (through standard errors reported in tables), and p-values (stated as < 0.0001 for significant comparisons) are reported.
The research is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The research is primarily quantitative; data coding and analysis are not applicable.
Results are clearly presented in tables (e.g., Table 1, Table 2, Table 3) and figures (e.g., Figure 4), with clear descriptions of the findings.
Section 7 discusses limitations, such as the assumption of constant student ability and the lack of deployment in live classroom environments.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
